newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: BP to shift regional head to Venezuela.
newsitem.headline: BP to shift regional head to Venezuela.

text.p: Oil giant British Petroleum Co Ltd said on Tuesday it would post a Latin American regional director in Caracas "in the next few weeks", shifting the position away from Bogota where it has traditionally been based.

The post is currently held by Bogota-based John Doust, who is also the head of BP's Colombian unit BP Exploration (BPX). A BP spokesman said Doust would not be moving to Venezuela but that the position would be filled by a new appointee.
Doust, the spokesman said, would leave Colombia to return to Britain "before the end of the year".

The spokesman rejected suggestions that BP's regional power base was being moved to Venezuela because of the protracted wrangle between BP and the state-run oil company Ecopetrol over the contract terms for the huge Piedemonte block in eastern Colombia.

"The reason for this (move) is simply because our business in Colombia is mature while business in Venezuela is young and needs the support of a senior person with experience and knowledge to give BP's business a push there," the spokesman told Reuters.
BP has had a presence in Colombia for about the last decade but only set up in Venezuela about three years ago.
BP is the major partner in Colombia's Cusiana-Cupiagua block, which is expected to be producing about 500,000 barrels a day by early 1998 and has major stakes in the Central and Ocensa pipelines.
The spokesman was unable to say what BP's daily production figure in Venezuela was.
He said BPX's operations would continue to be run from Bogota while the new Latin American director would run Venezuelan and other region-wide operations.
The spokesman was unable to say who had been appointed to the post of Latin American regional director or who would replace Doust as head of BPX.
